AUSTRALIA'S FIRST TEST TUBE BABY

At the birth of

a miracle I

Australia's miracle baby, Candice Elizabeth (above), and with her proud parents, Linda and John Reed (right).

"lt's just miraculous!"

said Dr lan Johnston

delightedly after the birth

of Australia's first test

tube baby, a perfect little

girl, Candice Elizabeth

Reed. Her birth will bring

hope to thousands of

childless women, as

Australia now leads the

world in this important

research field. But your

help is needed for

research to continue

In a room charged with emotion and

excitement, Candice Elizabeth Reed,

Australia's first so-called test tube

baby, entered the world with a whimper

that quickly grew to a yell.

After a night that at times seemed

endless to her 26-year-old mother, Linda

Reed, Candice was born normally at 7.09

on a grey winter's morning, June 23, at

Melbourne's Royal Women's Hospital

family birth unit.

As Candice was drawn slowly into the

hands of obstetrician Mr Ian Johnston,

one of the team that made her possible,

he said delightedly: "It's just miracu-

lous! We're all immensely relieved."

John Reed, 30, beside his wife

throughout her labour, kissed Linda and

held her, as Candice was gently placed on

her chest. Linda and John wept with joy.

and even members of the nursing staff

shed some silent tears.

Candice was born as a result of the

hospital's programme of in vitro fertiliza-

tion and ovum transfer (known as

PIVOT) and present at the dramatic

birth were the programme's team mem-

bers, obstetrician Mr Ian Johnston, Dr

Alex Lopata, Dr Andrew Speirs, and Dr

Ian Hoult. Pediatrician Dr Ken Moun-

tain was also in the delivery room. After a

brief cuddle, Candice was handed to Dr

Mountain for examination.

"Has she got everything?" Linda jj

asked anxiously. Dr Mountain replied j

At the birth

of a miracle

FROM PAGE 2

jubilantly, "She is a perfect baby."

Candice, weighing a beautiful 3.58kg (71b

L4oz), was sponged with warm water,

wrapped in a blanket and returned to her

parents. It was then that she met her

four-year-old brother, Daniel.

Daniel, sitting on the bed. was allowed

to hold her. But it was debatable whether

he was more delighted with her or the red

plastic skateboard which he confidently

informed everyone she had brought with

her for him.

Candice was born five days before her

due date. "She did it herself," Linda said

happily. It may have helped, however,

that on the afternoon Linda's membrane

ruptured (or, as it is commonly described,

her water broke) the family went for a

ride on a Melbourne tram.

The tram was crowded and no one

stood up to offer Linda a seat. Shortly

after returning to their motel near the

hospital Linda "began to feel some

action." John and Daniel drove her to the

hospital and she was admitted about 6pm

on Sunday, June 22. Linda chose to have

her very special baby in the hospital's

family birth unit, which was opened last

October.

The hours dragged by, with John

leaving Linda's side only momentarily to

stretch his legs or check on Daniel.

Linda's contractions began in earnest

about 5am and after an examination -

and encouraging words - Mr Johnston

explained that Candice was in an occipito

posterior position (in other words she was

facing upwards rather than downwards).

Most babies turn 180 degrees during

birth, correcting the position.

Candice was not doing this and Linda

was in increasing pain. At 6.30am, Mr

Johnston decided she should have an

epidural. He rang the hospital's director

of anaesthesia, Dr John Paull, who

arrived within minutes to administer the

pain-numbing drug to Linda.

Near the end of her labour, it became

necessary for Mr Johnston to use forceps

to gently turn the baby into the correct

position for birth.

It was about this time that the Reed

family became the stars of their own film.

A film crew from Channel 9's 60 Minutes

filmed the birth to provide Mr Johnston

and the hospital with a documentary.

Candice is a second miracle for the

attractive young couple who married

believing they could never have children

of their own. Daniel was their first.

Linda's tubes had been damaged

during a childhood case ol' appendicitis

and doctors had told her she could never

have a baby.

"Then one day. after we'd been

none Help

An unforgettable moment for Linda

and John with Daniel, 4, and newly

born Candice Elizabeth.

Pictures:

Don McPhedran and Neville Waller.

married a couple of years, I had the

feeling I was pregnant," Linda recalled as

we sat in the family's immaculate,

modern brick house one day last summer.

Linda did her own pregnancy test at the

hospital and was astounded to find it

"positive."

Linda's pregnancy with Daniel was

normal - just as her second one with

Candice was - but he came into the

world feet first, a breech birth.

In the few years after Daniel's birth.

Linda suffered with three ovarian cysts,

until finally her chances of ever again

conceiving by normal methods were

absolutely nil.

"Then we read about the test tube

baby in England . . . and finally plucked

up courage to go to our family doctor and

ask if any similar work was being done

here. He referred us to Mr Ian Johnston

at the Royal Women's Hospital," Linda

said.

After a "trial run," Linda was called

back to Melbourne at the end of last

September so that her impending ovula-

tion could be closely monitored. On

October 1, she was admitted to thc

hospital.

Linda spent three days in the hospital

waiting for her egg, fertilized with John's

sperm, to be implanter! And then "on

Friday, October 5, they came to me and

said 'We've got to put it back'."

She then had to spend 24 hours lying

flat on her back, "terrified of sneezing!'

It was. after that, a very long drive back

home to Churchill.

Churchill is a town of 4500 people in

the Latrobe Valley. John, who grew upin

the area, is a primary school teacher.

Shortly after Candice's birth, while

Linda lay peacefully breastfeeding her

dark-haired daughter, John walked out

in the Melbourne cold (eight degrees) in

his shirtsleeves. "I don't need a coat. I

won't even feel it!" he laughed.

As he left, he shook Mr Johnston'sand

Mr Lopata's hands. "Thank you." he

said. "Good on you, Johnno," Mr

Johnston replied.

After a day etched forever on her

mind, Linda slept soundly, waking only

to feed her daughter, a daughter her

thrilled mother says looks "so like Daniel

at that age that it could be him."

John and Daniel were back with

"their girls" at the hospital after a solid,

12-hour sleep at their motel. While

Daniel sat propped with cushions on a

divan, holding Candice and gently

stroking her hair, Linda said: "I'm glad

it's over - but it's still hard to believe.

Although I had a lot of pain during

Candice's birth, I'd do it all over again

even if I had twice as much pain."

Linda said that for nine months, she

none Help

had never considered the possibility of

there being "something wrong" with

Candice. "And then when my contrac-

tions started, I spent about 10 minutes

lying there worrying whether she'd have

an extra arm or something."

John did not share her concern. "At

least I was relaxed about that," he

laughed. "All the tests Linda had had

during her pregnancy showed that

Candice was all right."

John, who was not permitted to be

present at his son's birth, could not find

words to describe his feelings at the first

sight of his daughter. "I just want to

make a recommendation to all fathers

that they should be présent when their

babies are born," he said.

John admitted to having some doubts

about Daniel being present in the

delivery room, but now says he and Linda

are glad he was there.

Daniel has now decided that he wants

to be a doctor when he grows up. He has

spent a lot of time with a stethoscope in

his ears listening to his sister's and

mother's heartbeats.

"Wouldn't it be wonderful if they were

both doctors and worked together in the

same kind of medical field that made

Candice possible?" Linda said, smiling.

"I think what you wish for your

children is a little more than what you

had for yourselves."

CANDICE: S5¡3T

the million dollar baby

Candice Elizabeth Reed is a name

that will be forever noted in the

annals of medical history. For she

is the world's third "test tube" baby and,

importantly, the first to be born outside

the United Kingdom where the method

of in vitro fertilization had its initial

success.

Her safe arrival makes Australia the

leading nation in in vitro (meaning "in

glass," hence "test tube") fertilization,

since the UK programme has been

virtually discontinued.

Candice is the culmination of a

decade's research and work for two major

Melbourne hospitals and their university

affiliates. The unique collaborative study

that led to her birth was carried out by

medical teams from the Royal Women's

Hospital and the Queen Victoria Medical

Centre, together with Melbourne Univer-

sity and Monash University.

This million dollar baby - the pro-

gramme has cost all that and needs more

money to continue - is mainly the result

of the combined work of Mr Ian

Johnston, Dr Alex Lopata, Dr Ian Hoult

and Dr Andrew Speirs, at the Royal

Women's Hospital.

More than 100 women have already

been involved in what is known as the

Programme of In Vitro Fertilization and

Ovum Transfer (PIVOT), and there are

still 150 on a waiting list spanning five

years at PIVOT's present rate.

Early attempts at in vitro fertilization

were disappointing. It wasn't until 1978,

when the success of Mr Patrick Steptoe

and Dr Bob Edwards in the UK resulted

in two healthy, live-born "test tube"

babies, that the Australian team decided

to make at least one major change to its

methods.

It stopped priming patients with drugs

- so that development of one or more

eggs was assured and a time for collecting

a ripe egg could be preplanned - and

began relying on the woman's own,

natural cycles.

About the same time, Dr Alex Lopata

achieved a major breakthrough in his

laboratory process.

Dr Lopata produced a culture media

which enabled 90 percent of a woman's

ripe eggs to be fertilized in the labora-

tory. This made it possible for a high

proportion of the fertilized eggs to grow

normally for three to four days in an

incubator in preparation for their trans-

fer to the patient's uterus.

Mr Ian Johnston and Dr Andrew

Speirs, relying on a patient's natural

cycle, used three-hourly urine tests and

ultrasonic scanning of the ovaries to

I-_

determine when the ëgg?T~wéise- ready.

Timing is of vital importance. Locating

the right egg is done with the patient

under general anaesthetic by making a

small incision and using a laparoscope

(an instrument used for internal examin-

ations, which emits a strong light).

Once located, the egg is gently picked

up with an aspirating needle - a delicate

suction instrument.

A couple of hours before the operation

to remove an egg, the patient's husband

has prepared sperm in a nearby room.

The egg is washed in a special fluid and

placed with a droplet of the sperm.

When the egg is fertilized, the embryo

starts to grow. The embryo is eventually

placed in a purified paraffin oil which

protects it during the critical time it is

being examined to decide whether it is

normal before transfer into the uterus by

way of the vagina.

Until now, women with blocked or

damaged fallopian tubes - like Linda

Reed's - have had no hope of ever

becoming pregnant. Tubal damage usu-

ally prevents the man's sperm from

fertilizing the egg during the woman's

ovulation.

Surgery can be done to correct tubal

blockages, but the operation is extremely

delicate and not always successful.

Although the fallopian tubes are ap-

proximately the size of a straw, their

inner passageways are only about the size

of thin sewing thread.

The tubes connect the fimbria, which

take the egg from the ovary and pass it

down the tube to the uterus. Inside the

tubes is the normal meeting place of

sperm and egg, where conception takes

place. The tubes are responsible for the

survival of the fertilized egg during the

three days it takes to reach the uterus.

During the journey, the egg takes

nourishment from highly specialized cells

along the tubal passage. This is vital,

because the egg must be strong enough to

make its niche in the lining of the uterine

cavity.

With in vitro fertilization, the egg is

removed by laparoscopy, fertilized in the

laboratory, kept alive in an incubator for

the period when it would normally be

moving down the fallopian tube, and

then re-implanted as a microscopic

embryo in its mother's womb.

All this might sound straightforward,

but it is not. Only dedicated team effort,

with some members on constant call day

and night, has made Linda Reed's in vitro

fertilization possible.

The Australian medical team's

success with PIVOT is a direct result of

its own experiments and studies.

It was during 1979 that the PIVOT

team began using women's natural

cycles. Until then, patients had been

given drugs to artificially stimulate egg

development.

It has been - and still is - exhausting

work for the PIVOT team which must be

on call 24 hours a day, seven days a week.

"We believe the programme is import-

ant," Mr Johnston said. "Research into

conception has the natural off-shoot of

providing information about contracep-

tion. It is also valuable in studying

human abnormality.

"Now we feel it is up to the commun-

ity to indicate whether it wants us to

continue with our work."

Although Mr Steptoe visited Mel-

bourne shortly after the world's first

"test tube" baby, Louise Brown, was

born in England, none of the crucial

scientific aspects of his work with Dr

Edwards was made available. It still has

not been fully documented in medical

journals.

The PIVOT team, which has been

visited by numerous doctors involved in

similar programmes overseas, is planning

to publish its findings in medical

journals.

The Australian work on in vitro

fertilization actually began 10 years ago

as a result of failure of another research

project at the Queen Victoria Medical

Centre, which was an artificial fallopian

tube - a plastic device designed to

replace a diseased or damaged tube in a

woman.

The device failed, but in presenting a

paper on it at the Australian Society of

Reproductive Biology in Melbourne,

Professor Carl Wood and colleagues met

an animal reproductive biologist, Dr Neil

Moore, who suggested the possibility of

examining egg collection, laboratory

fertilization, and transfer of the early

embryo back to the patient.

Professor Wood spent a week examin-

ing Dr Moore's work on fertilization of

sheep and was convinced of the possibil-

ity of using the technique for human

reproduction. It was already known that

Mr Steptoe and Dr Edwards were

attempting similar feats in the UK.

In 1971, the Royal Women's Hospital

became interested in vitro fertilization

after Mr Ian Johnston heard Dr Edwards

address the International Infertility

Society Meeting in Tokyo.

It was with mutual interest and aim

that the two hospitals (the Queen

Victoria and the Royal Women's) and

their university affiliates, began working

on the programme that has made

Australian - and world - history.

The Programme of In Vitro Fer-

tilization and Ovum Transfer

(PIVOT) is in danger of ending.

Unless funds are quickly raised to keep it

going, there will be no more "test tube"

babies born in this country.

This means that many thousands of

infertile Australian women will be denied

the chance of ever having a baby.

It also means that a spin-off from the

programme, vital research into methods

of contraception, will end.

For these reasons, The Australian

Women's Weekly is launching a public

appeal for funds to keep the programme

operating.

"We need at least $100,000 a year to

continue our research at its present

rate," said Mr Ian Johnston, leader of

Melbourne's Royal Women's Hospital

PIVOT team.

Mr Johnston has asked the Federal

Government and the Victorian State

Government for financial aid. In both

instances, it is "under consideration.

Although more equipment - incuba

tors and microscopes - is needed, M:

Johnston says "we desperately neec

salaries." Highly qualified scientists are

currently working up to seven days s

week for $15,000 a year.

The team has been working with ont

incubator, costing $4000, and one $6(XX

microscope. The North Balwyn Women;

Auxiliary of the Royal Women's Hospita'

has raised the money to buy a second

microscope.

Since the PIVOT team began using 6

system based on a woman's natural cycle

more than 100 women have taken parti"

the programme (and many others are

waiting). Of these, only three have

successfully conceived. Two later mis-

carried, leaving Linda Reed Australia s

only mother of a "test tube" baby.

Mr Johnston and his team believe

that the programme is "potentially

enormous." It could have direct apphca'
